Allow advanced users to enforce JSON response types in XHRs.

Allow advanced users to enforce JSON response types in XHRs.

Add support for setting the XHR `responseType` property to `"json"`.  This
defines the response data as JSON and prevents the browser from handling other
types of data.  It allows JSON parsing to be done off of the main thread,
reducing CPU contention that can happen with large responses and low-power
devices; this can yield smoother animations during navigation, for example.
However, it prevents processing chunked responses on-the-fly (i.e.
pseudo-streaming), effectively eliminating most of the benefits of multipart
responses.  Guard this behavior behind an "advanced" config flag and provide
no default to prevent accidental usage.  Setting `advanced-response-type-json`
to `true` will enable the feature.

Merge pull request #303 from nicksay/reset-scroll-on-event

Alternate approach to prevent early scrolling during navigation.

Alternate approach to prevent early scrolling during navigation.

The current approach to preventing early scrolling during navigation uses the
the current position during a history change event and scrolls to that position
after the event has been handled using `setTimeout`.  This leads to a brief
flash of incorrect position (aka jank) during history navigation because too
much time elapses between the browser's early scroll and the reset call.

Instead, during the history change event, save the current position.  During
the next scroll, if a position has been saved, scroll to it immediately (and
delete the saved position).  This executes the reset call in the same
synchronous operation as the browser's early scroll and eliminates the flash
of incorrect position.

When handling a history change event, save the current position and scroll to

Animation: Deprecate combo CSS classes in favor of discrete ones.

Previously CSS animation classes had to target both the history direction
(forward/back) as well as the animation point (start/end) via a combination
class, even if the properties were shared:
```
.spf-animate-forward-start .spf-animate-new,
.spf-animate-forward-end   .spf-animate-old,
.spf-animate-reverse-start .spf-animate-new,
.spf-animate-reverse-end   .spf-animate-old {
  opacity: 0;
}
```

Now, the classes will be split into discrete ones that represent a single
target only:
`.spf-animate-forward-start  ->  .spf-animate-forward.spf-animate-start`
`.spf-animate-reverse-end  ->  .spf-animate-reverse.spf-animate-end`

This allows less verbose CSS when doing animation that does not change based
on history direction.

Add support for sending an HTTP header to identify requests.  This provides an
alternate system for negotiation between SPF and default browser requests, but
it adds a restriction on developers: a `Vary` header MUST be returned by the
server to avoid caching problems.  Guard this behavior behind an "advanced"
config flag and provide no default to prevent accidental usage.

A normal SPF request looks like
```
GET /path?spf=navigate
```

By setting `url-identifier` to `null` and `advanced-header-identifier` to
`__type__`, a SPF request would then look like
```
GET /path
Accept: application/json
X-SPF-Request: navigate
```

And the server must then return
```
Vary: Accept
```

[git-p4: change = 61296854]

Allow for partial responses during transitions. This requires two changes to spf.

First, SPF now sends an additional request header 'X-SPF-Previous-URL'. This contains the URL of the page which proceeds the loading page. It can be used to make decisions about what parts of the page to reload. It's usually the same as the referer, but differs when history events occur. In those cases the Previous-URL header represents the previously visible page, while the referer represents the original page that lead into the target.

Second, SPF now accepts a cache-suffix in the response. This is appended to the cache key to limit responses which should only be used in certain situations. This is then matched up against the lead in page's URL to determine if cache can be used.

I like the flexibility of the suffix in the response, but I'm not in love with the key generation mechanism, so I'm very open to suggestions here.

SPF: Update caching logic to differentiate between requests.

Whereas before a single caching pool was shared among all types of
requests, now there is differentiation between history navigation,
standard navigation and prefetching, and load requests are not
cached.

The new logic is as follows:

Writing to cache:
  - standard navigation writes to the history cache
  - history navigation writes to the history cache
  - prefetching writes to the prefetch cache

Reading from cache:
  - standard navigation reads from the prefetch cache and, if found,
    moves the entry to the history cache
  - history navigation reads from history cache
  - prefetching does not read from any cache

The previous logic is available if the "cache-unified" config flag is set.

SPF: Add XHR processing support for chunked transfers and add Response
processing support for multipart responses. Used together, an SPF
request can be processed in stages as it arrives, similar to standard
HTML rendering.

This CL introduces multipart responses and ensures that they can be used
interchangeably.  It also starts splitting navigation-related methods
into functional namespaces and unit tests.

The unchanged transfer format for a single (traditional) response is
an object serialized in JSON:
  '{ "css": "...", "html": {...}, ..., "js": "..." }'

The unchanged object for a single response after parsing this format is:
  {
    'css': '...',
    'html': { ... },
    ...,
    'js': '...',
    'timing': { ... }
  }

The new transfer format for a multipart response is an array of objects
serialized in JSON, where '[\r\n', ',\r\n', and ']\r\n' delimiters
are used to facilitate on-the-fly parsing:
  '[\r\n
   {"css": "..."},\r\n
   {"html": {...}},\r\n
   ...,\r\n
   {"js": "..."}
   ]\r\n'

The new object for a multipart response after parsing this format is:
  {
    'type': 'multipart'
    'parts: [
      {'css': '...'},
      {'html': { ... }},
      ...
      {'js': '...'}
    ],
    'timing': { ... }
  }

SPF: Change navigation history/request order so the Referer header is usually correct.

Now, standard navigation in response to a click or JS navigate call will have the correct referrer sent.  This is done by sending the XHR for the next page before adding the new history entry.  However, back/forward navigation in response to browser history events will still be wrong because the browser changes the URL before the XHR is sent.  In both cases, an additional X-SPF-Referer header will be sent with the correct value.

Replace the "navigate-started-callback" and "navigate-history-callback" notifications with a single unified "navigate-requested-callback" notification that is published for either link clicks or history events.  Remove unused "load-received-callback" and "load-processed-callback" notifications, which are redundant with passed callback functions.

Also, minor fixes to the demo app to properly display the referer and to mark external scripts as loaded.


[git-p4: change = 47724795]

SPF: Set the "X-SPF-Referer" header on navigate requests.
Since the browser URL has already updated by the time the navigate request
is made and will be incorrectly sent as "Referer", setting "X-SPF-Referer"
allows the actual referrering URL to be sent as well.  The header is only
sent for navigate requests, because "Referer" will be correct for load and
prefetch requests.
